title: Which is the best headphone for listening music? - Quora

response.answer_text: Like any consumer product, with headphones a lot of what you are paying for isn’t actually the headphones. Most headphones are made in some factory in the far east for next to nothing, and what you pay for is the cost of transporting them, storing them, marketing them, getting them reviewed, getting well know people to be seen using them, and so on and so on. So to get the “best” headphones you need to get away from consumer items. Have you ever watched a band play live, and seen the things they have in their ears? Those are called “in ear monitors” and they sound fantastic. Like really fantastic. The reason why they sound so good is they are very much a boutique product, they are very expensive and they are designed for the most discerning ears. Let me tell you about my pair of them.  See how they have the initials DS on them? Those are my initials. Every pair of these headphones is custom made to fit EXACTLY the ear canal of the customer. Before you have a set made for you, you have to go to an audiologist, and have “impressions” made. This is when they inject wax into your ears to find the exact shape of your ear canal. Then, once this wax is set, you remove it (which is a weird and slightly painful experience) and send them to the manufacturer. There are a few companies that do this, but Ultimate Ears and JH Audio are the two that are probably most used at the top end these days. Mine are a set of JH 11s. JH11 PRO Each one has 4 speaker drivers in it. 2 for low, one for mid and one for top, as well as a 3 way passive crossover to make this possible. Also, as they are made to my specific ears, they are a perfect fit and block out more outside noise than a pair of foam ear plugs. What you have is a pair of Audio microscopes. I can hear things with these that I can’t even notice on top of the range studio monitors. There is sometimes TOO MUCH detail. When working with Audio on them you can become obsessed with tiny details that you simply can’t hear on any other listening system. If you want the best quality headphones money can buy, get a pair of these. These aren’t even top of the range, there is a JH13 above it, but they are even more expensive, and I have been told it’s a case of diminishing returns, and not really worth the extra. I can’t vouch for this personally though as I’ve never had a pair made. They are expensive though. To get the impressions made, send them to the US, have them manufactured, shipped back, and pay the import taxes on them was close to £1000GBP. But if what you want is the best pair of headphones you will ever hear, forget about consumer brands and get a pair of these.

You have specifically asked about headphones, not earphones or in-ear monitors. If you’re willing to get custom in-ear monitors, others (notably Dave Samwell) have provided information about that. The best of them can cost several thousand dollars but they’re worth it if you like that type of device. Most people do; a minority vehemently don’t. Now, to your question as stated: As for headphones, I have several preferences and that, preferences, is exactly what all this is about. Depending on the electronics used to drive the headphones and depending on your favorite type(s) of music, only your ears can make the choice. The “best” are generally open-back ‘phones where the design lets out the music to be heard by people near you and also lets in environmental noise. I spend time in noisy environments so those aren’t suitable for me. See what I did there? I removed consideration of an entire class of ‘phones, open-backs, because of my personal preference for sound isolation. While I could cite various name brands and models (and I will, in a moment), the way to find the best for you is to first decide on a basic style/design. Closed back ‘phones if you need isolation,Open back ‘phones if you don’t,On-ear if you like that design and find it comfortable,Around-the-ear if you find that more comfy (I know I do.),Basic other comfort considerations that can only be determined by putting them on your head for a while,Durability for the intended use (If you need portability, they need to be surprisingly durable.), andAny other factors you deem relevant (This includes price, a factor I’m ignoring since you asked about “best”).Note that “sound quality” is not listed above. That’s because there’s no use falling in love with the sound of a set that are completely unsuitable for your physical environment. For example, there are wonderful-sounding ‘phones out there that are designed to be left at your desk and only used there. Attempting to travel with them would result in them getting broken the second time you tried to stuff them into a suitcase. With the above basic design criteria in mind, you should be able to read the literature and come up with a short list, consisting most likely of the top-level ‘phones from: Audeze,HiFiMan,Focal,JPS Labs,Sennheiser,Stax,Sony,Mr. Speakers,Audioquest,Ultrasone,Abyss,oBravo,Sonoma, orsome brand that has slipped my mind.Note: The price of entry starts at about USD$1500 and goes up past USD$10,000. Now, this is the critical part. When you’re spending that much money on ‘phones, you’d be stupid to not listen to them first. Just putting them on your head and listening to one favorite song will make the differences between them manifestly obvious. How so? There will be very expensive ‘phones that you won’t use because of the fit.There will be very expensive ‘phones that, for some reason you can’t articulate, just don’t sound right to you. (Trust your gut and your ears and forget them.)There will also be less expensive ‘phones you’ll love because they are comfortable and sound great.You must try before you buy. That means going to: CanJam in the U.S.,Rocky Mountain Audio Fest in the U.S.,Axpona in the U.S,Munich High End in Europe,some other show I don’t know about,a local audiophile meet-up where people come to show off their toys, ora well-stocked local dealer who has a variety to test. Such dealers are virtually non-existent but if you have one near you, use that resource.Listen to everything on your short list and make a decision. It won’t be terribly difficult if you’ve done a good job of narrowing down your short list by design criteria and don’t get distracted by something that doesn’t meet your real-world environmental needs. Personally, I live in an environment where I may have to close out external sound sources and I certainly don’t want to share my music with anyone nearby. With those criteria in mind, I chose the Sony MDR-Z1R for its incredibly clarity. After tentatively making a choice, however, you really should test it with various headphone amps to make sure that the combination truly works. That, however, is beyond the scope of the question. PS - If anyone tries to sell you some Beats by Dr. Dre by telling you they are “high end” or “high quality” or “excellent sound”, you’re dealing with a rip-off artist. Beats are fine if you want to ridiculously over-pay for a style that impresses tween-age girls. If you want real music, though, stay far away from those awful things.
